bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, October 31, 1922

div1.p: Rose informs Carter that the International Health Board plans to continue yellow fever work in Mexico and possibly in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, October 31, 1922

October 31, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
At the meeting of the International Health Board held on
October 24, 1922, the following program in yellow fever control
was presented for 1923 and approved:
A. To continue cooperation with Mexico

B. To cooperate with Brazil, if invited, with a
view to exterminating the remaining focus
of infection in the region about Pernambuco
and Bahia

C. To send one or more competent persons to make
a thorough inspection of the Caribbean littoral
and the Amazon Valley with a view to ascertain-
ing whether this region is free from yellow
fever infection

D. To send representatives to West Africa to ascer-
tain what yellow fever control measures are
feasible and to formulate plans for future
work

With respect to work in Mexico, the program is, to con-
tinue intensive work in all regions where work is now in progress
until the end of the present year; to continue intensive work in
Vera Cruz, Tampico, and Merida until May, 1923; and to keep the
whole of Mexico under observation throughout 1923.

At the present time, so far as we know, the only infected
regions remaining on the Western Hemisphere are Eastern Mexico and
a narrow coastal zone in Eastern Brazil. Since January 1, 1922,
there have been reported in Mexico 20 cases of yellow fever, with
12 or 13 deaths. Fifteen cases have occurred since the first of
July in and about Panuco and Tampico. The mosquito breeding index
in this territory has been greatly reduced during the last few
weeks and is now below 5 per cent in the areas in which the infec-
tion occurred.

A death, diagnosed as yellow fever, occurred on the
schooner “William E. Burnham” on September 13, 1922, just before
the vessel arrived at quarantine in Mobile, Alabama. The schooner
left Sierra Leone for the United States on June 25, stopping at
Paramaribo, Dutch Guiana, en route. This case is now under inves-
tigation. If it was yellow fever, it raises the question whether the
infection came from West Africa or from Dutch Guiana.

In West Africa, the epidemic which was reported during
August at Grand Bassam, Ivory Coast, has apparently subsided.
Reports not yet confirmed have been received of one death from
yellow fever in Togoland and one in Christiansburg, Gold Coast.
This outbreak would seem to settle the question as to the presence

of yellow fever in Africa. It is now proposed therefore, that
with a proper understanding on the part of government author-
ities involved, the Board send one or more representatives
to ascertain what may be done in the way of control measures.

We should welcome suggestions from you as a member
of the Yellow Fever Council, concerning the program proposed
for the coming year.

Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor Henry R. Carter
